Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: An Ozone-Based Field Sterilizer for Rapid sterilization and Reuse of N95 Respirators and other PPE in Response to COVID-19
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impacts of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop a new rapidly dry-sanitizing technology for disposable single-use personal protective equipment (PPE) and other articles in a manner that preserves material integrity and function to enable multiuse during pandemic and post-pandemic times. It will promote energy and water conservation, and reduce plastic waste significantly. This ozone-based sanitization technology will benefit all frontline workers regularly exposed to infectious diseases such as COVID-19. The need for rapid sterilization technology is likely to grow to mitigate social distancing configurations. Schools, daycare centers, health and fitness facilities, factories, and airports will need to implement sterilization protocols. With this technology, clothes, face shields and masks, phones, smart devices, and all manner of personal articles can be easily sanitized in less than ten minutes. The market for small industrial-scale waterless appliances with the capacity to offer on-demand sterilization may also expand rapidly. While ozone is used in a wide range of sterilization technologies, there is currently no consumer-friendly dry washing machine. Thus, this project may also support development of an eco-friendly and effective laundry solution. Together, the sanitization and safety tasks will advance this technology as a viable waterless sanitization device, with the distinct advantage of lower cost, compact size, operational ease, and accessibility.<br/><br/>The proposed project advances translation of a low-cost, rapidly deployable gas-based field sanitizer that does not require water, solvents, or detergents. To combat infectious viruses and odor-causing bacteria, this technology must meet aggressive benchmarks set by federal regulatory agencies for ozone emissions while achieving the highest bioburden reduction levels short of an autoclave. This project will optimize the ozone dose (ppm and time of exposure) required for viral inactivation and testing mask fit and filtration efficiency after repeated exposure to high ozone concentrations. The device will also incorporate new containment and neutralization technologies to meet environmental safety requirements. The device performance will be characterized by monitoring the exhaust for residual ozone during and after operation.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The report focuses on the development and testing of a new disinfection technology using ozone gas. The goal of the project was to create a commercially feasible and lab-tested safety system that could easily be incorporated into products by manufacturers. The research team confirmed the hypothesis that ozone gas could degrade certain materials at extended exposure levels but also found that there is a healthy margin between biocidal doses and doses that damage materials.

The project objectives included evaluating the effectiveness of using ozone gas to disinfect N95 respirators and hard surfaces, as well as measuring the fit and filtration efficiency of N95 respirators after multiple cleaning cycles and testing the risks of residual ozone gas exposure by users of such a cleaning cycle. The project team inoculated sterile respirator coupons and glass coverslips with a wide array of organisms per FDA guidelines and market development interviews for general-purpose medical disinfection. The team found that gas-based ozone technology can be used to efficiently neutralize a wide array of viruses, bacteria, and fungi in medical, industrial, and consumer settings. The team also found that N95 respirator material can withstand multiple sterilization cycles at ozone concentrations exceeding the concentration and duration necessary for significant viral inactivation, but the elastics were deformed beyond use after 20 cycles. The team also found that the filtration material itself can withstand 100+ cycles before exhibiting signs of failure. The team also found that the filter media of a new ozone safety system fails between 50 and 100 cycles with wide variability. Further research is needed to increase media lifespan and develop sustainable recharging protocols, but such a system is ready for larger-scale commercial, military, and industrial beta testing and use-case exploration today. 

The broader impact of this technology is significant, as it has the potential to improve public health during crises such as pandemics, natural disasters, or supply shortages. Ozone gas can be used as a powerful tool for point-of-use generated, rapidly deployable disinfection, making it a valuable addition to the arsenal of tools used to combat the spread of disease. The technology is easy to manufacture, portable, and ruggedized, making it suitable for use in a wide range of settings.

The team also found that as more data becomes available and a better understanding of ozone gas is gained, computer-controlled sanitization models could be developed for use on even the most sensitive materials. This could lead to the development of new products and applications for the technology, further increasing its impact on public health and safety.

Overall, the project has demonstrated the potential for ozone gas-based disinfection technology to have a significant impact on public health and safety and has laid the foundation for further research and development in this area. The team's work has de-risked the technology, making it more attractive for manufacturers to incorporate into their products, and has opened up new possibilities for the use of ozone gas in disinfection and sanitation.
